p: Bagasse is generated during the sieving or straining stage, where the pulp is separated from the fibrous material, constituting 10% of the processed cassava residue [ 150]. This residue contains a high percentage of water and starch residues because it is soaked in water in the starch separation stage. Under these conditions, bagasse presents a higher volume than the raw material represented by 60 to 90% of water and 10 to 30% of starch and fiber in dry weight [ 163]. Due to its fiber content, it provides lignocellulosic characteristics due to the cellulose (22%), hemicellulose (35%), and lignin contents ( Table 8) [ 164].
